entry.title: Seamlessly Expand from Event Mesh to Advanced Event Mesh with Our New Export Feature
entry.content:
Have you started your event-driven journey with the Event Mesh capability in SAP Integration Suite? It's the perfect service to begin, offering direct integration with SAP S/4HANA events and a focused feature set that caters to low to moderate event volumes. It’s ideal for businesses just beginning their EDA journey.

As your EDA implementation matures and expands, you may need to handle higher event volumes, require more sophisticated eventing capabilities, or need broader landscape coverage.

We are excited to announce that you can now easily expand from Event Mesh in SAP Integration Suite to SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh to meet those demands. SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh is a separately priced offering that unlocks a new level of event management with powerful features, including:

  • Event Streaming: Handle massive volumes of events with advanced features like queuing, streaming, and replay.
  • Partitioned Queues: Ensure ordered processing by publishing messages with similar contexts to the same consumer.
  • Dynamic Message Routing: Automatically determine how to forward event messages within and across clusters.
  • Distributed Tracing: Trace the complete lifecycle of an event as it travels through the event mesh.
  • Flexible Deployments: Extend beyond public and private cloud environments to hybrid and on-premises broker deployments.
  • Event Management: Create, design, share, and manage various aspects of your EDA.
  • Event Monitoring and Insights: Curated dashboards, clear visualizations from historical and real-time metrics, with timely event broker notifications.

Learn more about SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh's key features and pricing here: What is Advanced Event Mesh?

Introducing "Export Configuration"

To make your transition journey smoother, we've introduced a powerful new feature directly in the Event Mesh UI: the "Export Configuration" button.

Screenshot of the Event Mesh in Integration Suite UI, featuring a new "Export Configuration" button in the top right corner

 

This new function is the first step to move to SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh by downloading the configuration artifacts from Event Mesh in SAP Integration Suite. With a single click, you can export your existing metadata — including queues, topic subscriptions, and settings — into a Terraform infrastructure-as-code (.tf) file.

To guide you through the expand process from Event Mesh to Advanced Event Mesh, we published a new migration guide. You can access it here: Migration from Event Mesh in SAP Integration Suite to SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh

How Does the Migration Work?

The new export feature is the starting point for a streamlined, five-step migration process:

  1. Export: Navigate to the Event Mesh capability in the SAP Integration Suite UI and click the new "Export Configuration" button to download your .tf file.
  2. Edit: Open the downloaded file and add the credentials for your new, empty SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh broker instance.
  3. Import: Use standard Terraform commands (init, plan, apply) to automatically provision your queues and topic subscriptions in SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh.
  4. Adapt Applications: Adjust your sender and consumer applications to connect to the new SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh endpoints. This may involve updating connection details, libraries, and topic wildcard syntax.
  5. Migrate Applications: Choose a migration strategy that fits your needs — either a phased, application-by-application rollout or a "big bang" switchover during a maintenance window.

This new process significantly reduces the manual effort and complexity previously associated with such a migration, allowing you to focus on leveraging the advanced capabilities of your new environment.

Ready to Get Started?

Unlock the full potential of your event-driven architecture and expand to SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh today.

For a complete, step-by-step guide on the entire process, please refer to our official documentation on the SAP Help Portal:

Migration from Event Mesh in SAP Integration Suite to SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh

entry.title: Enhancing SAP Business Events with Custom Payload Fields using RAP
entry.content:
Introduction

When working with SAP Event Mesh and business partner events, you might encounter scenarios where the default event payload contains only basic information, such as the Business Partner ID.

Below topic is configured in /N/IWXBE/OUTBOUND_CFG

Create BP

Check /IWXBE/EVENT_MONITOR

You see only Business partner ID in the payload.

However, business requirements often demand additional contextual data like first name and last name to be included in the event payload. This blog post demonstrates how to enrich SAP business partner events with custom fields using derived events.

The Challenge

By default, when a Business Partner is created or modified in SAP S/4HANA, the outbound event payload typically contains only the Business Partner number. While this is sufficient for basic integrations, many real-world scenarios require additional information to avoid unnecessary callback requests to the source system.

Solution Overview

We can leverage SAP's event binding mechanism and receiver function modules to create derived events that include custom fields in the payload. This approach allows us to:

  • Enhance event payloads with additional business data
  • Reduce the need for subsequent API calls
  • Improve integration performance and efficiency
  • Maintain clean separation between standard and custom logic

Implementation Steps

Step 1: Create Abstract entity

define abstract entity Z_ABSTRACT_ENTITY_BP
{
  businesspartner : abap.char(10);
}

Step 2: Create root view entity with the field which you want to add in the payload.

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Add fields to standard Business Event Payload'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.usageType:{
    serviceQuality: #X,
    sizeCategory: #S,
    dataClass: #MIXED
}
define root view entity Z_CUSTOM_PAYLOAD_BP
  as select from but000
{
  key name_first,
  key name_last
}

Step 3: Create behavior definition and behavior implementation class as shown below.

managed implementation in class zbp_custom_payload_bp unique;
strict ( 2 );

define behavior for Z_CUSTOM_PAYLOAD_BP //alias <alias_name>
persistent table but000
lock master
authorization master ( instance )
{
  event bpchanged parameter Z_ABSTRACT_ENTITY_BP;
  event bpcreated parameter Z_ABSTRACT_ENTITY_BP;
}
CLASS zbp_custom_payload_bp DEFINITION PUBLIC ABSTRACT FINAL FOR BEHAVIOR OF z_custom_payload_bp.
  TYPES: tt_events_change        TYPE TABLE FOR EVENT z_custom_payload_bp~bpchanged,
         tt_events_create TYPE TABLE FOR EVENT z_custom_payload_bp~bpcreated.
  PUBLIC SECTION.
    CLASS-METHODS:raise_bp_changed
      IMPORTING it_events TYPE tt_events_change,
      raise_bp_created IMPORTING it_events TYPE tt_events_create.
ENDCLASS.

CLASS zbp_custom_payload_bp IMPLEMENTATION.
  METHOD raise_bp_changed.
    lcl_event_handler=>on_bp_changed( it_events ).
  ENDMETHOD.
  METHOD raise_bp_created.
    lcl_event_handler=>on_bp_created( it_events ).
  ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.

In local types of Behavior implementation class,

CLASS lcl_event_handler DEFINITION FRIENDS zbp_addr_changed.

  PUBLIC SECTION.
    CLASS-METHODS: on_bp_changed IMPORTING it_events TYPE zbp_custom_payload_bp=>tt_events_change,
      on_bp_created IMPORTING it_events TYPE zbp_custom_payload_bp=>tt_events_create.

ENDCLASS.

CLASS lcl_event_handler IMPLEMENTATION.

  METHOD on_bp_changed.
    RAISE ENTITY EVENT z_custom_payload_bp~bpchanged FROM it_events.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD on_bp_created.
    RAISE ENTITY EVENT z_custom_payload_bp~bpcreated FROM it_events.

  ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

Step 4: Create Custom Event Definition

Step 5: Configure custom event in the outbound bindings

Step 6: Create receiver function module

This will intercept the standard Business Partner event and raise the derived event with enhanced payload:

FUNCTION ztest_bp_receiver_fm.
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------
*"*"Local Interface:
*"  IMPORTING
*"     VALUE(EVENT) LIKE  SWETYPECOU-EVENT
*"     VALUE(RECTYPE) LIKE  SWETYPECOU-RECTYPE
*"     VALUE(OBJTYPE) LIKE  SWETYPECOU-OBJTYPE
*"     VALUE(OBJKEY) LIKE  SWEINSTCOU-OBJKEY
*"  EXPORTING
*"     VALUE(REC_ID) LIKE  SWELOG-RECID
*"  TABLES
*"      EVENT_CONTAINER STRUCTURE  SWCONT
*"  EXCEPTIONS
*"      READ_FAILED
*"      CREATE_FAILED
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------
  SELECT SINGLE name_first,name_last FROM but000 WHERE partner = @objkey INTO (ls_bp).
  IF sy-subrc IS INITIAL.
    zbp_custom_payload_bp=>raise_bp_changed( it_events = VALUE #( (
                                                         name_first = ls_bp-name_first
                                                         name_last = ls_bp-name_last
                                                         %param = VALUE #( businesspartner = objkey )
                                                         ) ) ).

  ENDIF.

ENDFUNCTION.

Step 7: Register Event Linkage

Link the standard Business Partner event to your receiver function module using transaction SWE2:

  1. Execute transaction SWE2
  2. Create a new entry with:
    • Object Type: Business Partner object type (e.g., BUS1006)
    • Event: The standard event (e.g., CHANGED)
    • Receiver Type: Function Module
    • Receiver Function Module: ZTEST_BP_RECEIVER_FM
  3. Save the configuration

Step 8: Test the Implementation

Now it's time to verify that everything works as expected:

  1. Modify an existing Business Partner (change any field)

 

2. Navigate to /N/IWXBE/EVENT_MONITOR

  1. Locate your derived event in the event list
  2. Examine the payload

 

You should now see an enriched payload containing:

json

 {

 "name_first": "Derived events",

 "name_last": "Demo",

 "businesspartner": "0001000260"

}

Important Note for BP Creation Events:

If you want to trigger the derived event at the time of Business Partner creation, you need to add an additional entry in SWE2 for the CREATED event. You have two options:

Option 1: Same Payload for Both Events If the payload structure is identical for both creation and modification events, you can use the same receiver function module for both events:

  • Create an entry in SWE2 for event CREATED pointing to ZTEST_BP_RECEIVER_FM
  • Create an entry in SWE2 for event CHANGED pointing to ZTEST_BP_RECEIVER_FM

Option 2: Different PayloadsIf you require different payload structures for creation and modification events, perform the following:

  • Create a separate receiver function module (e.g., ZTEST_BP_RECEIVER_CREATE_FM) for the creation event
  • Implement the custom logic for the creation payload
  • Add a separate entry in SWE2 for event CREATED pointing to the new function module
  • Keep the existing entry for CHANGED event pointing to ZTEST_BP_RECEIVER_FM

Best Practices

  • Always handle database read errors gracefully
  • Consider performance implications when querying large datasets
  • Document your custom events clearly for API consumers
  • Use meaningful naming conventions for custom events and function modules
  • Test thoroughly in development before deploying to production
  • Monitor event processing to ensure reliability

Conclusion

Derived events provide a powerful mechanism to enhance standard SAP events with custom business data. By following the steps outlined in this blog post, you can significantly improve the value of your event-driven integrations without modifying standard SAP objects.

This approach maintains clean separation between standard and custom code while providing the flexibility needed for real-world integration scenarios. Whether you're building microservices, integrating with external systems, or creating event-driven architectures, enriched event payloads will help you build more efficient and maintainable solutions.

Additional Resources

  • Steps to publish business events 

Have you implemented derived events in your SAP landscape? Share your experiences and questions in the comments below!

Event-driven architecture SAP Event Mesh

entry.title: Everything you need to get started with SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh
entry.content:
Introduction - Why Now Is the Moment to get started with Event-driven Architecture

As enterprises accelerate their journey to the cloud, business requirements are evolving at a rapid pace. SAP S/4HANA is increasingly being positioned as the digital core - designed to support greater agility, continuous transformation, and real-time responsiveness. In globally distributed organizations, the demand for instant data access and the need to decouple core systems from fast-moving innovations are defining a new dimension of how businesses operate.

Despite this shift, several integration challenges stand in the way of a seamless cloud transformation:

  • Traditional on-premise integration technologies are no longer sufficient to meet the speed, flexibility, and scalability required by today’s hybrid, cloud-based landscapes.
  • Modern integration approaches must be cloud-native and hybrid by design, capable of operating reliably across regionally distributed environments and ecosystems.
  • Real-time, event-based integration is becoming the emerging best practice, especially for high-volume, data-driven scenarios such as omnichannel commerce and intelligent supply chains.

SAP’s Answer?

SAP has developed a comprehensive response to these evolving needs by extending the SAP Integration Suite with modern, event-driven capabilities:

  • SAP Integration Suite provides powerful, cloud-ready tools and methodologies to enable integration across heterogeneous IT landscapes - on-premise, cloud, or hybrid.
  • Legacy on-premise integration architectures can be efficiently transformed into scalable, cloud-based models to meet today’s agility and performance requirements.
  • Event-driven integrations complement traditional methods by enabling real-time, loosely coupled interactions between systems - powering new business models and dynamic processes.

To support this, SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh offers a fully managed, enterprise-grade event streaming and management service which includes a robust set of features built for enterprise needs:

  • A distributed mesh of event brokers that can be deployed across any environment - public or private cloud, on-premise, or hybrid setups.
  • Elastic scalability, from small-scale projects to very large enterprise-grade use cases, without compromising performance or reliability.
  • Comprehensive support for event streaming, event management, and event monitoring, ensuring full visibility and control.
  • An advanced management toolset with features like message routing, filtering, deployment configuration, and distributed tracing to ensure seamless operations.

 

Complementing Traditional Integration Approaches

While event-driven architecture opens up new possibilities, it’s not a replacement - it’s a powerful complement. SAP Integration Suite continues to serve as a leading integration platform-as-a-service (iPaaS), enabling smooth integration of cloud and on-premise applications. Advanced Event Mesh enhances this by delivering a global, enterprise-grade event mesh, complete with the tools needed to operate and optimize it for maximum business value.

 

What is the value of Event-driven Architectures?

Today’s enterprise IT landscapes are often burdened by legacy integration patterns that are no longer fit for purpose. These outdated methods not only limit agility but also introduce complexity, latency, and inefficiencies across systems. Several common patterns highlight the limitations of traditional integration:

  • Batch Delivery introduces delays in transmitting information across systems.
  • Point-to-Point Connections result in a tangled web of integrations that are brittle and hard to scale.
  • Periodic Polling causes unnecessary system load and latency, constantly checking for updates.
  • Decentralized Data leaves critical information scattered and siloed across various domains.

With digital transformation accelerating and real-time responsiveness becoming essential, this traditional approach simply can’t keep up. Modern businesses need an integration model that is more flexible, scalable, and event-aware. This is where event-driven architecture comes into play. Rather than building rigid connections between applications, this model embraces asynchronous communication, where events trigger actions across a loosely coupled ecosystem. The advantages of this approach are clear:

  • Broadcasting: Events are published across a mesh; applications can subscribe to what’s relevant to them.
  • Decoupling: The publisher doesn't need to know who consumes the events, simplifying development and enabling flexible scaling.
  • Filtering: Subscribers only receive the information they’ve explicitly asked for - nothing more, nothing less.

By shifting to an event-driven mindset, enterprises can significantly reduce integration complexity, respond to changes in real time, and create more resilient, adaptive system architectures.

Many organizations are held back by spaghetti architectures - a tangle of point-to-point integrations that are hard to manage and slow to adapt. These rigid systems make it difficult to innovate, scale, or respond quickly to change.

 

To break free, modern enterprises are adopting a publish-subscribe model powered by events and APIs. Instead of tightly coupled connections, applications communicate through a shared event mesh and standardized APIs - creating a modular, flexible integration layer.

This shift enables:

  • Faster rollout of new services
  • Real-time data flow across systems
  • Easier reuse and scaling of integration assets

By moving to an event- and API-driven architecture, you lay the foundation for scalable, agile digital transformation.

 

Resources for the Architect persona: The System Strategist

Event-driven architecture enables real-time visibility into business operations by mirroring key business moments as events (e.g., OrderPlaced, CustomerSignedUp). This empowers decision-makers to:

    • Respond faster to market and customer changes
    • Unlock real-time analytics and insights
    • Drive automation and efficiency across business processes
    • Build a digital foundation for future innovation (AI, ML, IoT)

entry.title: Handling Deletion Scenarios at Item Level in SAP ASAPIO Outbound Integration to Solace AEM
entry.content:
Handling Deletion Scenarios at Item Level in SAP ASAPIO Outbound Integration to Solace AEM

In complex SAP integration scenarios, managing item-level deletions effectively is essential for maintaining data accuracy across connected systems. This blog explores how ASAPIO’s Outbound Integration framework can be configured to detect, process, and publish deletion events at the item level toward Solace AEM (Advanced Event Mesh). We’ll use the Change Document–based event model (CDHDR/CDPOS) and review how to ensure deleted line items are correctly represented in outbound payloads.

Understanding ASAPIO Outbound Messaging

ASAPIO’s Outbound Messaging framework integrates tightly with SAP’s Business Object and Change Document architecture. When a data change occurs, ASAPIO listens to the event (e.g., through SWEC or SWE2 linkage), captures it as a change pointer, and transforms it into an outbound message—usually in JSON format—to external systems such as Solace AEM.

The Challenge: Deletion at Item Level

Deletion events at the item level can be tricky because SAP’s Change Document entries often represent deleted items with blank item numbers. Without proper filtering and mapping, this can result in incomplete or missing data in the outbound message. To address this, we configure the SWEC event linkage and apply field restrictions to correctly trigger deletion events.

Configuration Steps

  1. **SWEC – Events for Change Documents**
       - Define the Change Document Object relevant to the business object (e.g., Sales Order, Purchase Order).In this case, we are using custom BO for opportunity and for item level we have created two events Edit and Deleted . We are interested in the deletion scenario here.

entry.title: Cheaper than you think: the Commercial Model of the Event Add-On for ERP explained
entry.content:
Cheaper than you think, more flexible than you expect: the commercial model of the Event Add-On for ERP explained

In the earlier blogs of this series on the Event Add-On for ERP we had already discussed what the event add-on is about and why you would want it. This blog here is about the commercials and to a certain extent about the deployment. This is because the commercials are strongly linked to the deployment of the add-on(s) and their linkage to the Advanced Event Mesh brokers that they hand their events over to.

Event Add-On at SAP Devtoberfest: well worth watching

Before we go there, I would like to point you to two sessions that we did at Devtoverfest just a few weeks ago. You can watch the recordings and specifically the Hands-On session is well worth it. Enjoy!

  • Warp-Speed for Event Creation: Overview on the Event Add-On for ERP

  • Hands-on Session: Practical Demonstration of the Event Add-On for ERP

Commercial Aspects of the Event Add-On for ERP

With that said, let’s now look at the commercial aspects of the Event Add-On for ERP:

  • The Event Add-On for ERP is now available via CPEA, BTPEA, and PAYG.
  • It works for SAP S/4HANA and ECC to create custom events in a low code / no code way.
  • Very important: this add-on only works in combination with SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh.

Why is it only available for use with Advanced Event Mesh? Because its commercials are bound to AEM. What does this mean?

  • The add-on gets activated on an AEM broker
  • You set a checkbox on your AEM broker named Add-On Connector Activation
  • This is what you get charged for – AEM brokers activated for the Event Add-On for ERP
  • The actual add-on is downloaded and installed on your backend
  • It can only be connected to activated AEM event brokers
  • You can connect several add-ons to the same activated AEM broker
  • You get charged only for the activated broker, not the installed add-ons
  • You could for example activate one AEM broker and connect add-ons on you ECC and your SAP S/4HANA system to it. You would get charged only for the activation on your AEM broker

In fact, there is no charge other than activated AEM brokers:

  • It does not matter how many custom events are created.
  • It does not matter how many events occur.
  • It does not matter if you combine different backends.
  • There is no consumption charge or anything like that.

Are there other things to keep in mind?

  • Activated brokers are charged on a monthly basis, meaning for a month
  • In the end, you do get a kind of flat rate
  • This means as well that if you activate a broker just for a day, you get charged for the entire month.

Tiered Pricing

The add-on comes with a tiered pricing. What does this mean? In the end it means that if you activate the add-on for more AEM brokers, the price per broker gets lower for newly activated brokers in a higher tier. Important: the price for the brokers in the lower tier does not change, it is the price for the additional brokers.

Find the latest information and the calculator in the SAP Discovery Center. 

A word on the Event-Add On for ERP in the SAP Discovery Center: since the add-on is linked to AEM, you can find the pricing under AEM. Scroll down to the lower part of the Pricing screen of AEM and you will find the pricing for the add-on. It is measured by Connections which is in the end AEM brokers activated for the Event Add-On for ERP. 

 

Pricing Examples

Find some pricing examples below to give you a practical indication of how things fit together.

One connection is charged - even if multiple backends / add-ons are connected - since the activation on the broker is metered, not the number of connected backends

Two connections are charged – since we meter the activated add-on connectors on the AEM brokers

Three connections are charged – since we meter the activated add-on connectors on the AEM brokers and there are brokers for Dev, Q and Prod

 

Summary

The Event Add-On comes with a tiered pricing. It is metered by the number of connections to AEM brokers. The connections need to be activated on the AEM brokers. If the activated connections reach a certain minimal number, the price per active individual connections is lowered according to the specific tier.

Important: if a connection is activated in a specific month for any period of time, the full charge for that connection for the specific month applies

Find the latest information and the calculator in the SAP Discovery Center. As said, look for it in the pricing for AEM since the add-on is bound to AEM.

entry.title: How AI Solutions Can Align with SAP’s Clean Core Principles
entry.content:
“Clean core” and “Artificial Intelligence” are often discussed in isolation. Clean core is positioned to reduce technical debt and keep SAP S/4HANA upgradeable, while AI is usually associated with new workloads, additional components, and non-SAP technologies such as Python.

This separation leads to a common misconception: that AI solutions, especially those implemented in Python or using external models, are incompatible with a clean core strategy.

In practice, AI and clean core are closely aligned. SAP’s own definition of an ERP clean core emphasizes standardization, modern extensibility, and the ability to leverage reliable data and AI innovations on top of a stable core. When designed correctly, AI solutions can fully comply with clean core principles and in many cases help to realize the intended benefits of the strategy.

SAP Clean Core Strategy

SAP describes an ERP clean core strategy as a set of guiding principles to keep business critical systems agile, cost-effective, and ready to adopt innovation. Key elements include:

  • Reduction of historically grown complexity and custom code in the core ERP system.
  • Standardization of processes by staying close to SAP best practices.
  • Use of modern extensibility options, particularly side-by-side extensions on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP).
  • API- first and event-driven integration, rather than direct database access.
  • Cloud readiness and continuous innovation, including the ability to exploit AI capabilities.

Clean core does not prohibit custom logic or non-ABAP technology. It defines where that logic should run (outside the S/4 core) and how it should integrate (through released, supported interfaces).

Principles Relevant for AI Solutions

For AI initiatives, the following clean core principles are particularly relevant:

  • Decoupled innovation: AI workloads should run outside the S/4HANA core, typically on SAP BTP, and consume data via published APIs or data services.
  • Use of official extensibility models: Extensions should follow the models described in SAP’s clean core and extensibility guidance, including in-app extensions, developer extensibility (ABAP Cloud), and side-by-side extensions.
  • API-first and event-driven patterns: AI components should use official APIs and events to interact with core applications, rather than relying on direct table access or modifications.
  • Governed data access: Data for AI models should be accessed through governed layers such as SAP HANA Cloud or SAP Datasphere, which preserve security, compliance and lineage.

If an AI architecture respects these principles, it is aligned with the clean core strategy, regardless of the programming language or specific AI framework used.

Clean-Core Compliant AI Architecture Patterns

Side-by-Side AI on SAP BTP

SAP’s “Generative AI on SAP BTP” reference architecture explicitly positions SAP BTP as the platform for AI workloads, with S/4HANA and other SAP cloud solutions used as systems of record.

In a side-by-side pattern:

  • SAP S/4HANA
    • Hosts standard business processes and transactional data.
    • Exposes business functionality via released OData/REST APIs and events.
  • SAP BTP (AI and application layer)
    • Runs AI workloads using SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad, where models and pipelines can be implemented in Python or other languages.
    • Uses SAP Generative AI Hub for LLM access, prompt orchestration, retrieval-augmented generation (RAG), and agentic scenarios.
  • Integration
    • Uses SAP Integration Suite, API Management and/or Event Mesh to connect AI components with S/4HANA through supported interfaces.

 

                       

AI workloads remain in the BTP extension layer, while SAP S/4HANA stays as the clean, standard core accessed via published APIs.

This pattern adheres to clean core because all custom AI logic and orchestration stay outside the S/4HANA core, while S/4HANA is accessed only via documented integration points.

AI Enabled Data Layer with SAP HANA Cloud

SAP has started using the term “AI enabled clean core with SAP HANA Cloud”, referring to architectures where S/4HANA remains the core ERP and SAP HANA Cloud provides an intelligent data layer for analytics and AI-driven applications.

Key characteristics:

  • Operational data is exposed or replicated from S/4HANA to SAP HANA Cloud or SAP Datasphere in a governed way.
  • AI models (classical ML or generative) are trained and executed against this data layer.
  • AI outputs are surfaced in side-by-side applications or written back into S/4HANA via APIs and standard extension points.

The core ERP remains clean and standard. AI driven logic is implemented in the surrounding data and application layers, which aligns with SAP’s stated goal of “increasing the pace of innovation and leveraging business value through reliable data and AI innovations” without compromising the core.

Programming Language and Clean Core Compliance

A frequent objection is that AI solutions are implemented in Python or with non-SAP frameworks and therefore cannot be reconciled with clean core.

From SAP’s standpoint, this is not correct. The clean core strategy focuses on minimizing custom code inside the core and using side-by-side extensions on SAP BTP to build new applications and innovations.

SAP’s own extensibility guidance explicitly acknowledges BTP side-by-side extensions implemented in ABAP Cloud, Java, Node.js and other languages. AI services developed in Python and deployed on SAP AI Core or container runtimes on BTP fall into exactly the same category.

Clean core compliance therefore depends on:

  • The location of the code (outside S/4HANA vs. in-core modifications).
  • The integration pattern (released APIs and events vs. direct table access).

It does not depend on whether the AI logic is written in ABAP, Python, Java or another language.

 

                                    

AI solutions built on SAP BTP and SAP HANA Cloud surrounding a clean SAP S/4HANA core, with integration strictly via APIs and events.

 

SAP’s clean core strategy is often misunderstood as a constraint on innovation. It provides the architectural discipline required to adopt AI at scale without compromising the stability and upgradeability of SAP S/4HANA.

By:

  • keeping AI workloads on SAP BTP and SAP HANA Cloud,
  • integrating through released APIs and events, and
  • applying SAP’s extensibility guidance consistently,

organizations can build advanced AI solutions that are fully aligned with clean core principles. The question is not whether AI is compatible with clean core, but whether AI architectures are designed to follow the same patterns that SAP itself recommends for any modern extension.

entry.title: Small but Great: Introducing Micro-Integrations for Advanced Event Mesh
entry.content:
The Mesh

SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh is more than just a broker – it allows you to build a mesh of event brokers. Once on the mesh, events can flow through your enterprise providing a veritable nervous system that allows your company to even become better in what you do – faster, more reactive, more scalable, more flexible, more open to your employee’s ideas and your customer’s and supplier’s technology.

Once on the Mesh

Now we have added to this “more than just a broker” – SAP has just, on November 28th, released Micro-Integrations for SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh.

Let’s go back to the second sentence you have read above: once on the mesh, events can flow … Often the question was: how do I get the events on the mesh from my event source, or off the mesh to the event consumer? Micro-Integrations facilitate exactly this on-ramp to and off-ramp from the mesh.

Micro-Integrations

Micro-Integrations are small, lightweight, event-driven integration modules that connect enterprise technologies (legacy and SaaS applications, messaging services, data bases, files, AI agents, etc.) to an event-driven distribution layer, so they can exchange information in real-time.  Advanced Event Mesh Micro-Integrations serve as on-ramp and off-ramp to the mesh – a network of meshed SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh brokers. 

Scope of Micro-Integrations

Micro-Integrations focus on specific, narrowly defined tasks or processes.  They are easier to design and change without impact to any other systems because the effect and risk of the change is localized.  The reason for this is that a Micro-Integration (MI) does not connect two applications with each other. A MI connects a given application as an event source to the mesh (On-Ramp) or event target from the mesh (off-ramp). Resulting from the event-driven approach and the power of Advanced Event Mesh, high throughput data streams flow faster.

Micro-Integrations include a source or target connector which establishes a data flow between an event distribution layer like an event mesh and some source/target system.

Micro-Integrations are available in the Cloud Console and allow you to manage and observe the state of an integration between your external system and an event broker service or event mesh. 

Benefits of Micro-Integrations

Micro-Integrations are highly beneficial for modernizing integrations with event-driven architecture and the benefits they offer include

  1. Greater Agility: easy to change how applications and services interact with one another
  2. Faster data distribution: better real-time performance than traditional integration patterns and fast streaming capabilities
  3. Better/Easy Scalability: improved scalability by use of pub/sub to distribute events and by option to add additional Micro-Integrations to specific task
  4. More Flexibility: different technologies can be used at source or target sides depending on best fit technology, commercials or technology evolution

Available Micro-Integrations

A number of Micro-Integrations are currently available for use with SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh and SAP adds new Micro-Integrations to this list frequently. The currently available Micro-Integrations include:

  • Azure Service Bus
  • Amazon SNS
  • Amazon SQS
  • MQTT
  • Network files services SFTP
  • IBM MQ
  • Google Pub/Sub
  • AWS SQS
  • Snowflake
  • Oracle Advanced Queuing
  • Salesforce 

More Micro-Integrations are planned to be made available.

Pre-Requisites and Commercials

Micro-Integrations require an SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh broker – a certain number of Micro-Integrations is included with the bigger AEM brokers. For the current commercial offering an Advanced Event Mesh broker of the 1K tier or higher is required (version 10.2.1 or later). The 1k broker for example includes a usage right for 2 Micro-Integrations which you can choose from the list of Micro-Integrations available for AEM.

Micro-Integrations are supported on Public Regions, Dedicated Regions, and Customer-Controlled Regions.

Understanding Micro-Integrations

A Micro-Integration defines how data should move between an external system and Advanced Event Mesh. A Micro-Integration includes a source or target connector which establishes data flow between an event distribution layer (i.e. Advanced Event Mesh) and some other source or target system.

So, there are two types of Micro-Integrations:

  • With a target Micro-Integration, data streams from an SAP event broker service to the external system.
  • With a source Micro-Integration, data streams from the external system to an SAP event broker service.

You decide at creation time whether to create a source or target Micro-Integration. A Micro-Integration contains up to five Flows that share the same connection information but differ in their endpoints. This allows you to group similar integrations and manage them as a single deployment, simplifying configuration and reducing operational costs.

The way forward

Customers with supported brokers can as of today use start using Micro-Integrations – supported again means a 1K broker or higher.

With the feature introduced, we intend to provide it in future via additional channels as well.

This is work in progress, so stay tuned for updates here.

Getting Started

Find additional information on Micro-Integrations for Advanced Event Mesh here:

Documentation
